posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: I began using GitHub and wanted to upload my code, as I had seen others do. However, when I tried to upload files from WPILIB, the following error appeared: ‚ÄúYowza, that‚Äôs a lot of files. Try uploading fewer than 100 at a time.‚Äù I would appreciate it if someone could explain how to properly upload files from WPILIB to my GitHub account.

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked: You do not upload files. Instead, you create a repository on GitHub and then push your local repository to it.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: You have to actually use Git, whether through the user interface in Visual Studio Code or through the command-line interface.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, git has a moderately steep learning curve, even for its basic functions. There‚Äôs no shame in starting out with the GitHub desktop app if the command line isn‚Äôt making much sense to you. I‚Äôll have to come back to it later, but there are plenty of video tutorials available if you‚Äôd like to get started.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Check out the WPILib docs as well. The FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation provides comprehensive guidance on getting started with Git version control. Git is a distributed version control system created by Linus Torvalds, best known for his work on the Linux kernel. It is designed to help track changes in code efficiently.

link_counts.title: Git Version Control Introduction ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
There is no shame in using the GitHub desktop app if the command line isn‚Äôt making sense. For some people, the way the UI displays diffs instead of relying on the clunkier command-line diff tool can make all the difference. People should use whatever tool they find most productive with.  

I highly recommend the desktop tool for anyone just starting with GitHub. If your team uses other Git servers or hosts their own GitLab, you may eventually need to learn the command-line interface or use an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) or code editor with built-in version control, like VSCode. While VSCode is decent, it can feel overwhelming when first opened.  

Still, any professional should learn the Git command-line interface to work effectively with shell environments, either remotely via shell or on a headless local machine, which is common in robotics.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Instead of using the clunkier command-line difference tool, you could try using **git difftool** or **git mergetool**, which allow you to utilize a visual diff/merge tool like Meld.
I would highly recommend using the user interface app called FORK. It works amazingly and is both simple and easy to use.
